body:
What ZAP version?
Would you mind checking ZAP's log file to see if there's any error? (file zap.log located in ZAP's default directory or the directory manually specified [1]).

[1] https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy/wiki/FAQconfig

ZAP version is 2.4.3 and I could not find the ZAP directory (windows 7 C:\Users<username>\OWASP ZAP)
Also, I don't remember specifying it manually.
Did you replace `<username>` with the actual user that you're using?

OK, might be hidden?
An alternative is to start ZAP with zap.bat file. [1]
It would output the error to the console, when generating the report.

[1] https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy/wiki/FAQinstall

Hi,
I was now able to check the logs and it showed error
2015-12-14 13:22:32,628 [pool-2-thread-1] WARN  ENGINE - data file enlarge failed 
java.io.IOException: There is not enough space on the disk

So I changed the drive to save the report and they are saved successfully.

Thanks for your guidance.

@sbunde thanks for letting us know. 

I'm going to re-open this one as we should probably handle that condition more gracefully.

rename.from: Empty xml and html report generated from ZAP

body: @kingthorin: How do you think this should be handled?

So originally I had thought this was about report generation failing, so I envisioned it going here:
https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy/blob/develop/src/org/zaproxy/zap/view/widgets/WritableFileChooser.java

However, this could have to do with a persisted session failing to grow properly (the HSQL DB), if that's the case we need to catch the condition and tell the user that they need to move their persisted session elsewhere (a disk with more space), else they're in a data loss scenario. What is further unknown at this point is how graceful HSQL is at dealing with full disks, we don't want to cause dialogs to just pop and pop and pop.
Looking [here ](https://github.com/arteam/hsqldb/blob/aa0a17fc0f4aad19afa42fb5afc46b4e0884601d/src/org/hsqldb/persist/RAFileSimple.java#L112-L126) it's only a warning, which is kind of surprising to me. I would assume that if the DB can't be grown you should see the error over and over again in ZAPs logs...

I guess. At this point more testing is needed to nail down the culprit, conditions, behavior, etc. then we can come up with a plan to address it.

@kingthorin I would like to work on this :). I was able to reproduce the error and I noticed you always end up with an IO error regardless of wether you were using the DB. The problem is that the exception is thrown after the user attempts to export the results to a disk w/o available space. As such, it would probably be useful to create a way to check if there is available space prior to exporting. I'd imagine the WritableFileChooser would need to be modified to accommodate this. #2376

issue.title: Issue 2127 Fixes IOException

repository.name: zaproxy
repository.description: The ZAP by Checkmarx Core project

issue.body: This is a rather small and simple fix for #2127 . However, it checks if there is available disk space prior to saving any results. Previously, ZAP attempts to save the file anyway which lead to an IOException being thrown that wasn't properly handled. I haven't internationalized the text just yet, because I'd like to get opinions. Please let me know if I'm missing something or should look into something else as well. Thoughts :) @psiinon @thc202 @kingthorin

body: Renaming this one seems like a good move. A separate issue can be raised referencing this one to cover what happens to session data (temp or persisted) when a drive fills up.

issue.title: IOException - data file enlarge failed

repository.name: zaproxy
repository.description: The ZAP by Checkmarx Core project

issue.body:
From https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy/issues/2127#issuecomment-164426383, the database "silently" fails (it just logs with warn level) when there's no disk space to increase the data file. At the very least, the user should be informed about that.

See also https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy/issues/2127#issuecomment-192188629, for more information.

rename.to: Warn if the report generation failed
